title: Who specifically would I send my manuscript to when sending it to a book publisher? - Quora

response.answer_text: Don’t bother. They won’t look at your ‘submission’ (writer, groveling). Historically, when manuscripts were physical collections of paper, all ‘submissions’ (writers, groveling) went onto the ‘slush pile’ and none were ever read. Publishers are not staffed to review ‘submissions’ (writers, groveling) and rely on agents to scout competent storytellers, fiction or nonfiction. Sending an email document attachment is not even possible with publishers today. They are not staffed to accept or review such ‘submissions’ (writers, groveling). You might try sending your ‘submission’ (writer, groveling) to an agent, but it won’t help. Agents are servicing their established authors and rarely accept new clients. Indeed, the odds of even getting a response or acknowledgement from an agent are very poor. Even then, you have no way to know whether the agent is competent and well connected to principal editors at publishing houses. And even if that book is accepted by an agent and submitted (writer, groveling) to a publisher, it must compete with all the known, established, revenue-producing writers already inside the system. The reality, today, is that a writer with a book, either of infinite wonder and worth or better suited for lining the birdcage, who wishes to gain the attention of an agent or publisher, faces odds of around 1:100,000 in gaining that book’s acceptance. That’s just a guesstimate and other Quorans may have better odds. Reality is better than self-delusion. The route to acceptance, publication and eventual monetizing of a writer’s work is long, hard and discouraging. And I derive no pleasure from explaining this. Here’s the thing: agents’ or publishers’ evaluations of manuscripts are totally subjective, entirely a matter of taste. Many best sellers were rejected repeatedly by supposed brilliant arbiters of potential publishing success; many works from supposedly wonderful authors receive huge advances, yet fail. In the words of the great screenplay writer, William Goldman: “Nobody knows anything.” He was referring to movies but with books it’s no different. All it takes is a lightning strike, followed by popularity, then a cult following, regardless of genre. Then agents and publishers will be beating a path to your door, telling you how wonderful you are. Good luck with that.

Whomever the publisher’s website says. If you are sending an unsolicited manuscript to an imprint of a mainstream publisher, assuming you’ve checked and they accept unsolicited manuscripts, it will go into a slush pile. At some point whatever person has been assigned to read it will pick yours up, take a look, and if you’re lucky keep reading long enough to at least warrant a halfway-personal rejection. If it’s someone that guarantees they’ll publish it, either you’ve already got a contract and should know the name of the person you’re dealing with or they’re a scam/vanity press and you shouldn’t be dealing with them at all.
